architecture.summary: Payload CMS is an open-source headless content management system and application framework built with TypeScript and React. It offers flexibility in content management and delivery through RESTful and GraphQL APIs. Users can choose between self-hosting or managed cloud services, depending on their needs. Payload CMS supports various databases, including MongoDB, PostgreSQL, and MySQL, providing developers with control over both backend and frontend integrations.

targetUsers.summary: Payload CMS caters to a broad spectrum of users, from individual hobbyists to large enterprises, offering scalability and customization to meet diverse content management needs. Its open-source nature and extensibility make it suitable for various project sizes and team structures.

legal.summary: Payload CMS is released under the MIT License, allowing for extensive customization and use. It is maintained by a commercial entity that offers additional enterprise features and support services.

userManagement.summary: Payload CMS includes a built-in user management system with role-based access control, enabling administrators to define permissions and manage user roles within the CMS.

contentEditing.summary: Payload CMS provides a web-based interface for content creation, supporting custom fields and content types. It offers versioning, previewing, and editing workflows to facilitate content management, though it lacks real-time collaboration features.

contentDisplay.summary: As a headless CMS, Payload does not include packaged themes or on-site display customization. Frontend development is required to design and implement the presentation layer, providing flexibility in delivering content across various platforms.

mobileSupport.summary: Payload CMS delivers content via APIs, allowing developers to build responsive designs, Progressive Web Apps (PWAs), or native mobile applications as needed. The CMS itself does not directly create these applications but serves as a backend content provider.

internationalization.summary: Payload CMS supports internationalization, enabling the management of multilingual content, user interfaces, and editor tools, making it suitable for global audiences.

extensibility.summary: Payload CMS is highly extensible through its plugin system, allowing developers to enhance functionality with custom plugins. Significant customizations typically require backend development expertise.

commerce.summary: Payload CMS does not include e-commerce features in its core offering and does not provide official extensions for commerce. Integration with e-commerce platforms would require custom development to meet specific business needs.

costs.summary: Payload CMS offers a free, open-source Community Edition under the MIT License. For advanced features and support, paid plans start at $22 per month. Users should also consider potential costs for hosting, plugins, and custom development.
